context_bundle.summary: Rust unsafe code for low-level operations, FFI for C interoperability, raw pointers, and safety invariants

common_patterns: Unsafe block: 'unsafe { let r = &raw const x; println!("{}", *r); } // dereference raw pointer'
Raw pointers: 'let mut num = 5; let r1 = &num as *const i32; let r2 = &mut num as *mut i32; unsafe { *r2 = 10; }'
Unsafe function: 'unsafe fn dangerous() { /* ... */ } unsafe { dangerous(); }'
FFI: 'extern "C" { fn abs(input: i32) -> i32; } unsafe { println!("Absolute value: {}", abs(-3)); }'
Calling Rust from C: '#[no_mangle] pub extern "C" fn call_from_c() { /* ... */ }'
Union: 'union MyUnion { f1: u32, f2: f32 } let u = MyUnion { f1: 1 }; unsafe { println!("{}", u.f1); }'
Static mut: 'static mut COUNTER: u32 = 0; unsafe { COUNTER += 1; }'
Transmute: 'let x: u32 = 42; let y: f32 = unsafe { std::mem::transmute(x) }; // dangerous'
known_errors: segmentation fault: Check pointer validity, ensure memory not freed
undefined behavior: Review unsafe code carefully, add safety comments
FFI type mismatch: Ensure C and Rust types match, use repr(C) for structs
memory leak: Ensure proper cleanup in unsafe code, use Drop trait
data race: Add synchronization in unsafe code, use atomic types
transmute unsound: Avoid transmute when possible, use safe alternatives
